skill.name: deployment-pipeline-design
skill.description: Design multi-stage CI/CD pipelines with approval gates, security checks, and deployment orchestration. Use when architecting deployment workflows, setting up continuous delivery, or implementing GitOps practices.
skill.summary: Design multi-stage CI/CD pipelines with approval gates, security checks, and deployment orchestratio...
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: No data theft or malicious execution patterns were found. The skill contains documentation and example snippets only. Network calls are illustrative and use placeholder endpoints.

content.value_statement: Teams often ship without clear stages or approvals and face risky releases. This skill provides pipeline structures, gate patterns, and rollout guidance to improve safety and delivery speed.
actual_capabilities: Defines standard CI/CD stages and a recommended ordering
Provides approval gate patterns for common CI systems
Explains rolling, blue green, canary, and feature flag strategies
Includes a multi stage pipeline example with build, test, deploy, and verify
Outlines rollback and monitoring practices for safer releases
limitations: Provides design guidance and examples, not runnable automation
References assets and references that are not included here
Assumes external tools like kubectl and security scanners
Does not configure or manage secrets stores

use_cases.title: Plan a staged pipeline
use_cases.description: Create a CI/CD design with build, test, staging, approvals, and production deployment.

use_cases.title: Choose rollout strategy
use_cases.description: Select rolling, blue green, or canary strategies based on risk and traffic patterns.

use_cases.title: Define release governance
use_cases.description: Set approval gates and verification steps for controlled production changes.

prompt_templates.title: Basic pipeline outline
prompt_templates.scenario: New team needs a simple CI/CD flow
prompt_templates.prompt: Draft a basic multi stage CI/CD pipeline for a web app with build, test, staging, approval, and production deploy.

prompt_templates.title: Approval gates
prompt_templates.prompt: Propose approval gate patterns for GitHub Actions and Azure Pipelines, including who approves and when.

prompt_templates.title: Strategy selection
prompt_templates.prompt: Compare rolling, blue green, and canary for a high traffic API and recommend one with reasoning.

prompt_templates.title: Full blueprint
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a full CI/CD pipeline with security scans, staging tests, approval, canary deploy, verification, and rollback.

output_examples.input: Design a CI/CD pipeline with approval and rollback for a Kubernetes service.
output: Stages: Source, Build, Test, Staging Deploy, Integration Tests, Approval, Production Deploy, Verify, Rollback
Approval: Manual gate after staging with a defined approver group
Deployment: Canary rollout with stepwise traffic shifts and health checks

best_practices: Run fast tests first to fail early
Keep staging and production environments aligned
Automate rollback using health checks and metrics
anti_patterns: Skipping approvals for high risk production changes
Using a single stage for build, test, and deploy

faq.question: What platforms are supported?
faq.answer: Examples cover GitHub Actions, GitLab CI, and Azure Pipelines, and the patterns apply to most CI/CD tools.

faq.question: What are the limits of this skill?
faq.answer: It provides guidance and examples only and does not execute or configure pipelines.

faq.question: Can it integrate with existing tools?
faq.answer: Yes, the patterns align with tools like Kubernetes, Argo Rollouts, and security scanners.

faq.question: Does it access my data or secrets?
faq.answer: No, it is static documentation and does not access files, secrets, or networks.

faq.question: What if my pipeline fails?
faq.answer: Use the rollback and verification guidance to isolate issues and restore a stable release.

faq.question: How does it compare to template skills?
faq.answer: This focuses on architecture decisions and tradeoffs rather than providing runnable templates.
